facts.text: Writ Petition No. 46 of 1972 filed in Original Jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 46 of 1972.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Khanna, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Khanna, J.

facts.text: Kanu Biswas filed petition under Article 32 for writ of habeas corpus from jail

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition through jail under article 32 of the Constitution for issuing a writ of habeas company-pus by Kanu Biswas,

facts.text: Kanu Biswas ordered detained by District Magistrate 24 Parganas under section 3 of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 to prevent acting prejudicial to public order

anchor.surface_text: who has been ordered by the District Magistrate 24Parganas to be detained under section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  Act 26 of 1971  with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Detention order made by District Magistrate on November 13, 1971

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention was made by the District Magistrate on November 13, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on November 14, 1971 and served with detention order and grounds with vernacular translation same day

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was arrested in pursuance of the detention order on November 14, 1971 and was served the same day with the order as well as the grounds of detention together with vernacular translation thereof.

facts.text: District Magistrate sent report to State Government on November 18, 1971

anchor.surface_text: On November 18,1971 the District Magistrate sent report to the State Government about the passing of the detention order along with the grounds of detention and other necessary particulars.

facts.text: State Government approved detention order on November 24, 1971

anchor.surface_text: The State Government companysidered the matter and approved the detention order on November 24, 1971.

facts.text: State Government sent report to Central Government on November 24, 1971

anchor.surface_text: Necessary report was also sent on that day by the State Government to the Central Government.

facts.text: State Government placed case before Advisory Board on December 13, 1971

anchor.surface_text: On December 13, 1971 the State Government placed the case of the petitioner before the Advisory Board.

facts.text: State Government received petitioner's representation on December 12, 1971

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, on December 12, 1971 the State Government received a representation of the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government rejected petitioner's representation on January 11, 1972

anchor.surface_text: The representation was companysidered by the State Government and was rejected on January 11, 1972.

facts.text: Advisory Board sent report on January 14, 1972 finding sufficient cause for detention

anchor.surface_text: The Board, after companysidering the, material placed before it, including the petitioners representation, and after hearing the petitioner in person, sent its report to the State Government on January 14, 1972. Opinion was expressed, by the Board that there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on February 2, 1972

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1972 the State Government companyfirmed the order for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: Affidavit filed by Shri B. Mukhopadhya, District Magistrate of 24-Parganas

anchor.surface_text: Affidavit of Shri B. Mukhopadhya, District Magistrate of 24- Parganas, who passed the impugned order, has been filed in opposition to the Petition.

facts.text: On September 26, 1971 at 18.30 hours, petitioner and associates attacked Baidyanath Bandopadhya and wife with knives in train and robbed wrist watch, gold ornaments, cash Rs.725/- creating terror and panic disturbing public order

anchor.surface_text: That on 26-9-71 at about 18.30 hours while Baidyanath Bandopadhya of Champapukur, P.S. Basirhat, District 24- Parganas along with his wife were travelling ill a 3rd class companypartment of Up Basirhat local train from Barasat, You along with your associates attacked him and his wife with open knives between Champapukur R s and Basirhat R S and robbed them of Wrist Watch, Gold Ornaments, Cash valued at Rs. 725/ - by putting them in fear of death. By your such activities you created terror and panic among the travelling passengers and public order was disturbed thereby.

facts.text: On November 4, 1971 at 21.40 hours, petitioner and associates armed with bombs, daggers, knives, iron rods attacked police at Beliaghata railway station platform, exploded two bombs, creating panic and confusion disturbing public order

anchor.surface_text: On 4-11-71. at about 21.40 hours, you and your associates armed with bombs, daggers, knives and iron rods etc. attacked police on the platform at Beliagliata railway station with a view to take their lives and to intimidate the public you charged two bombs which exploded with terrible sound endangering the on-duty police. Your such action was so violent that it created panic and companyfusion among the passengers there then. YOU have thus action in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Petitioner argued that acts not germane to maintenance of public order

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued on behalf of the petitioner that the particular acts on account of which the order for the detention of the petitioner has been made were number germane to the maintenance of public order and, as such, the order for his detention companyld number be validly made for preventing him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Court found incidents of September 26, 1971 and November 4, 1971 prejudicial to public order

anchor.surface_text: Each one of the above two incidents of September 26, 1971 and November 4, 1971, in our opinion, affected public order and number merely law and order.

facts.text: Past activities of petitioner showed propensity to disturb public order

anchor.surface_text: The past activities of the petitioner as revealed in the grounds of detention, in our opinion, showed a propensity to disturb public order.

concepts.unlisted_label: Acting in manner prejudicial to maintenance of public order
concepts.unlisted_description: Statutory ground for preventive detention under MISA s.3

anchor.surface_text: The test to be adopted in determining whether an act affects law and order or public order, as laid down in the above ,,case, is Does it lead to disturbance of the current of the companymunity so as to amount to a disturbance of the public order ,or does it affect merely an individual leaving the tranquility of the society undisturbed ?

concepts.interpretation: Applied to robberies in train and bomb attack on police at station, finding they created terror, panic, confusion, disturbing even tempo of community life and public tranquility

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ividuals which do number disturb the society to the extent of causing a general disturbance, of public tranquility. It is the degree of disturbance an

concepts.unlisted_description: Degree of disturbance and effect on community life distinguishes law/order from public order

anchor.surface_text: He companysidered three companycepts, law and order, public order and the security of the State, and observed that to appreciate the scope and extent of each one of them, one should imagine the companycentric circles. The largest of them represented law and order, next represented public order and the smallest represented the security order

concepts.interpretation: Explains hierarchy: law and order (widest), public order (narrower), security of State (narrowest)

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: for instance, a man stabs another. People may be shocked and even disturbed, but the life of the companymunity keeps moving at an even tempo, however

concepts.unlisted_description: Analogy for scope of law/order, public order, security of State

anchor.surface_text: Public order is the even tempo of the life of the companymunity taking the companyntry as a whole or even a specified locality. Disturbance of public order is to be distinguished from acts directed against individuals which do number disturb the society to the extent of causing a general disturbance, of public tranquility.

concepts.interpretation: Court applied to find train robbery and station attack disrupted even tempo by causing general panic among passengers

issues.text: Whether the particular acts on account of which the order for the detention of the petitioner has been made were germane to the maintenance of public order such that the detention order could validly be made under section 3 of MISA to prevent him from acting prejudicially to public order

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued on behalf of the petitioner that the particular acts on account of which the order for the detention of the petitioner has been made were number germane to the maintenance of public order and, as such, the order for his detention companyld number be validly made for preventing him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

issues.text: Whether each of the two incidents (September 26, 1971 train robbery and November 4, 1971 railway station attack) affected public order and not merely law and order

anchor.surface_text: Each one of the above two incidents of September 26, 1971 and November 4, 1971, in our opinion, affected public order and number merely law and order. The distinction between the companycept of public order and that of law and order has been adverted to by this Court in a number of cases.

issues.text: Whether the past activities of the petitioner as revealed in the grounds of detention showed a propensity to disturb public order

anchor.surface_text: The past activities of the petitioner as revealed in the grounds of detention, in our opinion, showed a propensity to disturb public order.

arguments.claim: The particular acts on account of which the order for the detention of the petitioner has been made were not germane to the maintenance of public order and, as such, the order for his detention could not be validly made for preventing him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued on behalf of the petitioner that the particular acts on account of which the order for the detention of the petitioner has been made were not germane to the maintenance of public order and, as such, the order for his detention could not be validly made for preventing him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court held each incident affected public order using tests from precedents like Arun Ghosh and Lohia, distinguishing from mere law and order, and found propensity to disturb public order

arguments.claim: In Sudhir Kumar Saha v. Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, similar acts of attacking with knives and hurling bombs were held not to prejudice the maintenance of public order

anchor.surface_text: Reference has been made on behalf of the petitioner to the case of Sudhir Kumar Saha v. Commissioner of Police, Calcutta. The petitioner in that case along with others committed various acts on three occasions.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: njured. The explosion of the bombs was stated to have created panic in the station, area and the adjoining locality. It was held that the activity of

arguments.court_reasoning: Court described it as a solitary decision and contrasted with other precedents relied on by respondent where similar acts affected public order

arguments.claim: On 26-9-71, petitioner and associates attacked couple in train with knives, robbed them creating terror and panic among travelling passengers and disturbed public order

anchor.surface_text: That on 26-9-71 at about 18.30 hours while Baidyanath Bandopadhya of Champapukur, P.S. Basirhat, District 24- Parganas along with his wife were travelling in a 3rd class compartment of Up Basirhat local train from Barasat, You along with your associates attacked him and his wife with open knives between Champapukur Rs and Basirhat RS and robbed them of Wrist Watch, Gold Ornaments, Cash valued at Rs. 725/- by putting them in fear of death. By your such activities you created terror and panic among the travelling passengers and public order was disturbed thereby.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court applied public order test from Arun Ghosh, finding act created terror and panic affecting even tempo of community life

arguments.claim: On 4-11-71, petitioner and associates armed with bombs etc. attacked police at Beliaghata railway station, exploded bombs creating panic and confusion among passengers prejudicial to public order

anchor.surface_text: On 4-11-71. at about 21.40 hours, you and your associates armed with bombs, daggers, knives and iron rods etc. attacked police on the platform at Beliaghata railway station with a view to take their lives and to intimidate the public you charged two bombs which exploded with terrible sound endangering the on-duty police. Your such action was so violent that it created panic and confusion among the passengers there then. YOU have thus acted in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court applied public order test from Arun Ghosh, finding violent attack with bombs created panic affecting public tranquility

arguments.claim: Principles from Arun Ghosh, Nagendra Nath Mondal, Tapan Kumar Mukherjee, Nandlal Roy, S.K. Kedar support that similar acts like train robberies and bomb attacks on police/RPF disturb public order

arguments.court_reasoning: Court found facts akin to Tapan Kumar Mukherjee and upheld detention based on similar reasoning

arguments.claim: Violation affects public order only if it affects community at large; law and order (widest circle), public order (middle), security of State (narrowest) per Lohia

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar, Hidayatullah J. as he then was said that any contravention of law always affected order, but before it could be said to affect public order, it must affect the community at large. He considered three concepts, law and order, public order and the security of the State, and observed that to appreciate the scope and extent of each one of them, one should imagine the concentric circles.

arguments.claim: Public order is even tempo of community life; test is whether act leads to disturbance of current of community life or merely affects individual; applied to facts

anchor.surface_text: In the subsequent case of Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal the Court dealt with the matter in the following words Public order is the even tempo of the life of the community taking the country as a whole or even a specified locality. Disturbance of public order is to be distinguished from acts directed against individuals which do not disturb the society to the extent of causing a general disturbance, of public tranquility.

arguments.claim: Each of the two incidents affected public order not merely law and order, as they created terror, panic, confusion disturbing even tempo of community life

anchor.surface_text: Each one of the above two incidents of September 26, 1971 and November 4, 1971, in our opinion, affected public order and not merely law and order. The distinction between the concept of public order and that of law and order has been adverted to by this Court in a number of cases.

arguments.claim: Past activities of the petitioner as revealed in the grounds of detention showed a propensity to disturb public order

anchor.surface_text: The past activities of the petitioner as revealed in the grounds of detention, in our opinion, showed a propensity to disturb public order.

holdings.text: Each one of the above two incidents of September 26, 1971 and November 4, 1971, in our opinion, affected public order and not merely law and order.

anchor.surface_text: Each one of the above two incidents of September 26, 1971 and November 4, 1971, in our opinion, affected public order and number merely law and order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Arun Ghosh test (disturbance of even tempo of community life) and Lohia concentric circles doctrine to facts of train robbery and railway station bomb attack, finding terror, panic, and confusion affected public tranquility beyond individual law and order.

holdings.text: In the light of what has been observed above, we have no doubt that each one of the incidents of September 26, 1971 and November 4, 1971 was prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of what has been observed above, we have no doubt that each one of the incidents of September 26, 1971 and November 4, 1971 was prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: After applying public order tests from precedents and analyzing impact on passengers (terror in train, panic at station), concluded acts disturbed even tempo of community life, justifying detention ground under MISA s.3.

holdings.text: The past activities of the petitioner as revealed in the grounds of detention, in our opinion, showed a propensity to disturb public order.

anchor.surface_text: The past activities of the petitioner as revealed in the grounds of detention, in our opinion, showed a propensity to disturb public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grounds of detention detailing two public order-disturbing incidents (train robbery, station attack) indicate propensity for future prejudicial acts, akin to Tapan Kumar Mukherjee case.

holdings.text: The facts of the present case are much more akin to those of Tapan Kumar Mukherjee and Ors. v. State of West Bengal supra.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished solitary contrary precedent (Sudhir Kumar Saha); followed multiple precedents (Arun Ghosh, Nagendra Nath Mondal, Tapan Kumar Mukherjee, Nandlal Roy, S.K. Kedar) where similar violent acts in trains/stations held to disturb public order.

precedents.citation: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar 1

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar 1 , Hidayatullah J.  as he then was  said that any companytravention of law always affected order, but before it companyld be said to affect public order, it must affect the companymunity at large.

precedents.case_name: Dr Ram Manohar Lohia v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between law and order, public order, and security of the State using concentric circles analogy; act must affect community at large to impact public order
precedents.cited_holding: any contravention of law always affected order, but before it could be said to affect public order, it must affect the community at large

precedents.citation: Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal 2

anchor.surface_text: Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal 2 the Court dealt with the matter in the following words Public order is the even tempo of the life of the companymunity taking the companyntry as a whole or even a specified locality.

precedents.case_name: Arun Ghosh v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Public order is even tempo of community life; degree of disturbance determines law/order vs public order; examples of stabbing in normal vs communal tension contexts
precedents.cited_holding: Public order is the even tempo of the life of the community... It is the degree of disturbance and its effect upon the life of the community in a locality which determines whether the disturbance amounts only to a breach of law and order

precedents.citation: Nagendra Nath Mondal V. State of West Bengal 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Principle on public order vs law and order distinction followed

anchor.surface_text: and Nandlal Roy Ca, Nonda Dulal Roy Pagla v. State of West Bengal  WP No. 15 of 1972, decided on March II, 1972.  In the light of what has been observed above, we have numberdoubt that each one of the incidents of September 26, 1971 and November 4, 1971 was prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

precedents.case_name: Nandlal Roy & Nonda Dulal Roy Pagla v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle on public order vs law and order distinction followed; bomb throwing during theft created public order disturbance

precedents.citation: Sudhir Kumar Saha v. Commissioner of Police, Calcutta A nr.  2

anchor.surface_text: Sudhir Kumar Saha v. Commissioner of Police, Calcutta A nr.  2 . The petitioner in that case along with others companymitted various acts on three occasions. On the first occasion lie attached the people of a locality with a knife and by hurling bottles at them.

precedents.case_name: Sudhir Kumar Saha v Commissioner of Police Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: Isolated attacks with knives, bottles, bombs not interlinked and not prejudicial to public order
precedents.cited_holding: the incidents were not interlinked and could not have prejudiced the maintenance of public order

precedents.citation: Tapan Ku-mat Mukherjee and Ors. v. State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Tapan Ku-mat Mukherjee and Ors. v. State of West Bengal 1  the allegation against the detenu was that he along with other associates companymitted robbery in respect of a fat, and a watch at the point of dagger in a running train, and this created disturbance of public order.

precedents.case_name: Tapan Kumar Mukherjee v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Robbery at dagger point in running train and bomb throwing created terror and public order disturbance
precedents.cited_holding: innocent passengers would be terror stricken; germane to disturbance of public order

precedents.citation: S. K. Kedar v. State of West Bengal  WP No. 35 of 1972 decided on May 2, 1972

anchor.surface_text: S. K. Kedar v. State of West Bengal  WP No. 35 of 1972 decided on May 2, 1972  the allegation against the detenu was that he and his associates while removing railway material charged bombs and ballast upon R.P.F. party as a consequence of which the members of R.P.F. party fired in self-defence.

precedents.case_name: S K Kedar v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Bomb and ballast attack on RPF while removing railway material prejudicial to public order
precedents.cited_holding: activity considered prejudicial to maintenance of public order; detention upheld
